+ Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 58.4
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
# The Weight of Iron The morning light crept through the narrow window of my cell like a thief, stealing the last moments of darkness I had come to cherish. I lay on the straw pallet, feeling its familiar scratch against my scarred back, and listened to Rome awakening beyond these walls. The ludus stirred around me. I heard Brennus coughing in the cell beside mine—a wet, rattling sound that had grown worse over the past weeks. The Gaul was dying slowly, though not from any wound earned in the arena. The irony was not lost on me. We who lived by the sword often perished by fever, by infection, by the simple cruelty of time and confinement. I rose and stretched, feeling the pull of old injuries across my shoulders and the familiar ache in my left knee where a retiarius had once caught me with the butt of his trident. Three years in the arena had mapped my body with such memories. Each scar was a story, each morning stiffness a reminder that I had survived another day. The smell of the ludus was something visitors never forgot—the sharp tang of sweat and iron, the earthier notes of straw and waste, all underlaid by the olive oil we used to make our skin gleam for the crowds. I had long since stopped noticing it, the way a fisherman no longer smells the sea. I reached beneath my pallet and withdrew my sica, running my fingers along the curved blade as I did every morning. The weapon was not officially mine—nothing here belonged to us—but Doctore had assigned it to me after my first victory, and it had become an extension of my arm. The sica was a Thracian blade, curved like a crescent moon, designed to hook around shields and find the flesh behind them. Its edge could open a man from hip to shoulder in a single stroke. But it was not the killing that made me love this weapon. It was the balance, the way it sat in my hand as though forged specifically for my grip. In a life where I owned nothing, controlled nothing, the sica was the one thing that felt truly mine. When I held it, I was not Marcus the slave, property of Gnaeus Cornelius Pulcher. I was something else entirely—something dangerous, something worthy of respect. The horn sounded for morning meal, and I joined the shuffle of bodies toward the common area. We moved like cattle, penned and directed, though we were fed better than most free men in the Subura. Pulcher understood that his investment required maintenance. Barley porridge thick with honey, bread still warm from the ovens, dates and figs—the food of athletes, meant to build the muscle and endurance that crowds paid to see. I sat beside Atticus, a murmillo from Hispania who had become something like a friend, though friendship here was complicated. Any day, we might face each other across the sand. "Did you hear?" he muttered, keeping his voice low. "Domitian attends the games next week." I felt something cold settle in my stomach. The Emperor's presence changed everything. When Domitian watched, the crowd's mercy meant nothing. He delighted in death, in the moment when a man's life hung suspended on his upturned or downturned thumb. Rumors said he had once ordered an entire troupe of gladiators executed for failing to entertain him sufficiently. "Perhaps he will be distracted by politics," I said, though I knew it was foolish hope. Atticus laughed bitterly. "When is Domitian not distracted by politics? They say he sees assassins in every shadow, plots in every whispered conversation." He paused, glancing around. "They say he is not wrong to be afraid." This was dangerous talk, the kind that could see a man's tongue cut out before he was fed to the beasts. But the ludus was full of such whispers lately. Rome herself seemed to hold her breath, waiting for something to break. The Emperor's paranoia had infected the city like a plague. Senators disappeared in the night. Philosophers were banished. Even the gladiatorial games had taken on a darker edge, as though the blood we spilled was meant to satiate something hungry in the Empire's soul. After the meal, we trained. The sun climbed higher, and the practice yard filled with the music of combat—the ring of wooden swords against shields, the grunts of exertion, Doctore's sharp commands cutting through the din. I worked through my forms with the sica, letting my body remember what my mind sometimes wished to forget. There was beauty in this, I could not deny it. The precise arc of a strike, the dancer's grace required to pivot and parry, the almost meditative focus that emptied my thoughts of everything but the next movement. In these moments, I understood why some men came to love the arena, why some volunteers—the auctorati—sold themselves into this life willingly. But then I would remember the faces of men I had killed. The young Germanian who had wept as he died, calling for his mother in a language I did not speak. The veteran from Capua who had nodded at me, accepting his fate with a dignity I still did not understand. The blood that had splashed hot across my chest, my face, my hands that would never truly feel clean again. The afternoon brought visitors to the ludus—wealthy Romans who paid for the privilege of watching us train, who looked upon us with a mixture of fascination and contempt. I saw a woman in silk the color of saffron, her eyes lingering on my body with an interest that made my skin crawl. We were entertainment to them, animals in a menagerie, objects of desire and disgust in equal measure. One of them would own me someday, I knew. If I survived long enough, if I earned enough victories, I might be granted the rudis—the wooden sword of freedom. But freedom for a gladiator was its own kind of cage. What would I be, beyond these walls? What could I become, with no trade but killing? The sica hung at my side, waiting for the arena's call. And Rome, eternal Rome, churned on around us, heedless of the blood that fed her glory.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical competence and historical authenticity in its portrayal of gladiatorial life in ancient Rome. The author successfully creates an immersive first-person narrative that avoids the obvious combat scene while still maintaining tension and interest. The historical details feel well-researched and authentic, from the ludus setting to the specific mention of Emperor Domitian's paranoia and the political atmosphere of the time. The author effectively weaves larger social and political themes into the personal narrative, particularly through the discussion of Domitian's reign of terror and its effects on Roman society. The sensory details are particularly strong - the description of the ludus's distinctive smell, the sounds of morning awakening, and the tactile experience of handling weapons create a vivid sense of place. The protagonist's relationship with his sica is especially well-rendered, serving as both a practical detail and a metaphor for his complex relationship with his circumstances. The character work shows depth and nuance. Marcus is neither a simple victim nor a romanticized hero, but a complex individual grappling with his circumstances. His conflicted feelings about the arena - finding beauty in the combat while being haunted by his victims - feels psychologically authentic. However, the piece suffers from some structural issues. The narrative meanders somewhat, moving from scene to scene without a strong central dramatic arc. While this captures the "slice of life" quality requested, it results in a piece that feels more like a character study than a compelling story with forward momentum. The prose is generally elegant but occasionally tips toward purple prose, particularly in some of the more philosophical passages. Some metaphors feel slightly overwrought, such as "Rome herself seemed to hold her breath" and the extended meditation on scars as stories. The ending, while thematically appropriate, lacks punch and feels somewhat anticlimactic. The final lines about Rome being "heedless of the blood that fed her glory" are thematically sound but don't provide a satisfying conclusion to this particular narrative slice. The piece succeeds in creating atmosphere and character depth but falls short of being truly emotionally gripping or dramatically compelling. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 12 Weak Dialogue: 16 Tell-Don't-Show: 15 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13 Amateurish: 16 Purple Prose: 12 Overwrought: 11 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 18 Unearned Transformations: 19 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 12.0, Weak Dialogue: 16.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 15.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13.0, Amateurish: 16.0, Purple Prose: 12.0, Overwrought: 11.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 18.0, Unearned Transformations: 19.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 83.0
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# The Lighthouse Keeper --- **14th September, 1923** Dear Mam, I am arrived safe at Rùm Mòr. The boat near killed me with the sickness but I kept my breakfast down which is more than the other man could say. The lighthouse is tall and white and stands on black rock like something from a dream you'd have after too much cheese. The keeper I'm replacing showed me the workings. Lenses and clockwork and paraffin. He could not wait to leave. Kept looking at the mainland like a dog waiting on its supper. The cottage is small but dry. There is a stove and a bed and a chair. I have hung your photograph above the mantel so you can watch me make a mess of the cooking. Send my love to Aileen and tell her I will write when I have something worth saying. Your son, Dougal --- **3rd October, 1923** Dougal, Your sister says you had better write her yourself or she will take the next boat out there and skelp you. You know she would do it. I am glad the posting suits you. Your father would be proud though he would never have said it. Lighthouse keeping is honest work. Better than the yards and what they did to his lungs. Mrs. Campbell asks after you every Sunday. I told her you were keeping the ships safe and she said you were a good lad. I did not correct her. The weather here is grey. Same as always. Write more. Tell me what you eat and what you see. I want to picture it. Your loving mother --- **19th October, 1923** Dear Mam, I eat tatties and tinned beef and sometimes a fish if I can catch one. The gulls eat better than I do. What I see is water. Water and sky and the line between them. Some days they are the same colour and I cannot tell where one ends and the other begins. It does something strange to your eyes. To your head. The light needs winding every four hours through the night. I sleep in pieces like a colicky bairn. When I wake in the dark sometimes I forget where I am and I think I am back in the room with Aileen snoring through the wall. I am not complaining. Only describing. There was a storm last week. The waves came over the rocks and the whole tower shook. I thought this is it then, this is how Dougal MacPherson ends. But it passed and I am still here. Your son, Dougal --- **2nd November, 1923** Dougal, You are worrying me. Your letters sound thin. Are you eating enough? Are you sleeping? Isolation is not natural for a young man. You should be out dancing and making a fool of yourself and falling in love with unsuitable women. I am sending a parcel with this letter. Shortbread and socks and a small thing I have been keeping. Your father's compass. The brass one his father gave him. You will remember he carried it all through the war though he had no use for it in the trenches. He said it reminded him which way was home. The glass is cracked but it still points true. Keep it in your pocket. Write to your sister. Your loving mother --- **27th November, 1923** Dear Mam, The compass arrived. I have been carrying it like you said. It is heavier than I remembered, or maybe I am just noticing weight more now. The brass has gone green in the creases where his fingers wore grooves into it. When I hold it I can feel the shape of his grip, the places where he rubbed his thumb waiting for something to happen or stop happening. The crack in the glass runs right across the face but you are right, the needle swings free. I have been checking it against the charts. It does not lie. I am sorry my letters have been thin. There is not much to report. The light works. The ships pass. I wind the clockwork and trim the wick and watch the beam sweep out across the black water. Sometimes I talk to myself just to hear a voice. Is that madness? It feels like something close to it. Your son, Dougal --- **15th December, 1923** Dougal, It is not madness. It is loneliness. They are cousins but they are not the same. Your father talked to himself all the time. Full conversations. Arguments sometimes. I would hear him in the garden debating with nobody about politics or football or whether the coal man was cheating us. He always won. You have three more months on your contract. You can survive three months. You survived that terrible school and the influenza and your own stubborn nature. I am proud of you. I should say it more. Write to your sister or I will tell her about the Matheson girl. Your loving mother --- **4th January, 1924** Dear Mam, Happy New Year. I brought the whisky up to the lamp room and toasted the midnight with the beam. The light swept round and I turned with it, watching it reach out over the water. There was a ship passing, far out. I could see her lights. I raised my glass to her and I like to think someone raised one back. I have been thinking about what you said. About loneliness and madness. I think maybe there is a third cousin. Something like clarity. When there is nothing else, you start to see yourself plain. No distractions. Just you and the work and the dark. I am not sure I like what I see. But I am looking. Thank you for the compass. I check it every morning. Home is still southeast. Your son, Dougal --- **23rd March, 1924** Dougal, The boat comes tomorrow. I will be at the harbour waiting. Aileen is making a pie. Mrs. Campbell is telling everyone. Your room is ready. Come home. Your loving mother --- **24th March, 1924** Mam, I am on the boat. The compass is in my pocket. The needle is steady. See you soon. Dougal
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative successfully fulfills most of the prompt requirements, creating a compelling story through correspondence between Dougal, a Scottish lighthouse keeper, and his mother. The piece spans approximately six months and effectively uses the letter format to reveal character and plot gradually. The Scottish working-class voice is authentically rendered without resorting to heavy dialect or stereotypes. Dougal's voice comes through clearly - practical, understated, with a dry humor that masks deeper struggles. His mother's voice is equally distinct - warm, concerned, pragmatic, with the kind of gentle authority that comes from experience. The contrast between their communication styles effectively reveals their relationship dynamic. The story's emotional arc is well-constructed, moving from initial optimism through growing isolation to a kind of hard-won self-awareness. The progression feels natural rather than forced. Dougal's psychological journey from confident newcomer to someone grappling with profound loneliness to finally achieving a form of clarity is believable and moving. The imagery is particularly strong - the lighthouse "like something from a dream you'd have after too much cheese," the description of water and sky blending together, the storm sequence. These details ground the story in sensory reality while serving the larger themes of isolation and disorientation. The father's compass serves as an effective symbolic element, connecting past and present, providing both literal and metaphorical direction. The detail about the worn brass and cracked glass adds authenticity and emotional weight. However, the story has some limitations. The resolution, while satisfying, feels somewhat abrupt. The transformation from deep isolation to readiness to return home could have been developed more gradually. The final letters are quite brief and don't fully capitalize on the emotional potential of the reunion. The piece occasionally tells rather than shows, particularly in passages where Dougal directly states his psychological condition rather than letting it emerge through more subtle details. Some of the metaphors, while effective, border on being too neat. The story avoids most common pitfalls - it's not overwrought, doesn't rely on purple prose, and maintains consistent quality throughout. The dialogue (within the letters) feels natural and serves character development well. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4 Unearned Transformations: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4.0, Unearned Transformations: 6.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 85.9
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Pattern Recognition The WiFi password is taped to the counter in 14-point Arial. "CafeRoma2019!" I clock it before we've even been seated, my brain filing it away like a squirrel hoarding nuts for a winter that never comes. Capital letter, proper noun, year, exclamation point. The bare minimum complexity requirement. Probably the same password on their POS system, their security cameras, maybe the owner's personal email. I could— *Stop it.* She's talking about her job. Marketing something. Content strategy. I force my attention back to her face, to the way she tucks her hair behind her ear when she's making a point. Her name is Maya. She has brown eyes. She laughed at my terrible joke about TCP handshakes. Focus on that. "So yeah, it's mostly B2B stuff, not super exciting," she's saying. "No, that's—I mean, content strategy is basically social engineering at scale, right? You're just hacking attention instead of systems." She tilts her head. Interested, not offended. Good save. The waiter approaches from my left. Mid-twenties, name tag says "Marcus," slight bulge in his apron pocket—phone, not wallet, based on the rectangular outline. He's wearing a watch that costs more than his weekly paycheck, which means either family money or debt. Neither relevant. Why am I cataloging this? Old habits. Seven years since I stopped doing things that could land me in federal prison, and I still can't walk into a room without mapping the exits and attack surfaces. We order. She gets the carbonara. I get something I won't remember because I'm too busy noticing the restaurant's security camera has a blinking red light, which means it's either fake or running firmware from 2015 that I could compromise with a Raspberry Pi and fifteen minutes. *Stop. It.* "So," Maya says, leaning forward slightly, "what do you do for fun? Besides, you know, computer stuff?" Here it comes. The moment where I either lie or watch her eyes glaze over. "I, uh... I play Magic: The Gathering. Casually. Mostly Commander these days." Her face does something unexpected. It lights up. "Wait, seriously? I haven't played in years, but I used to run a mono-black devotion deck that was absolutely disgusting." "Mono-black devotion? Gray Merchant?" "Four copies. No mercy." And suddenly we're off, talking about mana curves and removal spells and that one time she top-decked a Mutilate to clear a board of seven creatures. She's animated now, hands moving, eyes bright. This is real. This is connection. This is what normal people do—they find common ground and build something on it, instead of probing for weaknesses and cataloging vulnerabilities. I'm actually enjoying myself. The carbonara arrives and I barely notice the waiter's phone briefly visible—iPhone, older model, no case, cracked screen. Didn't notice the lock screen. Progress. "I still have my old cards somewhere," she's saying, pulling out her phone to show me something. "I think I have a photo of my collection from when I moved last year—" She swipes up. Her unlock pattern traces an L-shape. Four nodes. Possibly the most common pattern after the Z-shape. I watch her finger leave a faint smudge trail on the glass, literally drawing a map for anyone who might pick up her phone later. *Don't say anything.* She's scrolling through photos. *Seriously, don't.* "Here, look at this chaos—" "Your unlock pattern is really insecure." The words are out before I can stop them. They hang in the air like a bad smell. Her thumb freezes mid-scroll. "What?" "I—sorry, I just—" I'm already drowning. "It's an L-shape, right? Four nodes? That's like, one of the top five most common patterns. And you can see the smudge trail on your screen, so anyone who grabbed your phone could probably figure it out in two or three tries, and I'm sorry, this is—this is a thing I do, I notice security stuff, it's my job, I wasn't trying to—" She's staring at me. Not angry, exactly. More like she's recalibrating something. "Did you just hack my phone? On our first date?" "No! No, I didn't hack anything, I just—observed. It's different. I observe things. Vulnerabilities. It's like..." I'm grasping now, desperate. "It's like how you probably can't watch a commercial without analyzing the target demographic and messaging strategy, right? Professional deformation. I see attack vectors. I can't turn it off." She's quiet for a moment. The restaurant noise fills the space between us—clinking glasses, murmured conversations, that WiFi password still screaming at me from the counter. "So you're telling me," she says slowly, "that you've been sitting here this whole time, cataloging ways to compromise this restaurant's security?" I consider lying. I don't. "The WiFi password is taped to the counter. It's probably the same password they use for everything. The security camera is running outdated firmware. Our waiter's phone has no passcode at all—I saw the home screen when he checked a notification. And yes, I noticed your unlock pattern, and I'm genuinely sorry, because this has been the best date I've had in months and I just made it weird." She's still staring. Then something shifts in her expression. "The waiter has no passcode?" "None. Swipe to unlock. Naked as the day Steve Jobs intended." A small smile. "That's worse than mine." "Significantly worse." "But mine is still bad." "It's not great," I admit. "I could show you some better options. If you wanted. Not now. Obviously not now. Maybe on a second date, if that's still—" "You know what?" She picks up her fork, twirls it in the carbonara. "Anyone who runs mono-black devotion understands that sometimes you have to sacrifice a few creatures to win the game." "Is that a metaphor?" "It's me saying you're weird, but interesting-weird." She takes a bite. "Show me a better pattern. After dessert." The WiFi password is still taped to the counter. I decide not to mention it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and adherence to the prompt's specific requirements. The author successfully maintains the first-person perspective of a reformed white hat hacker throughout, with the internal monologue format working effectively to show the protagonist's compulsive pattern recognition and vulnerability assessment. The restaurant setting is well-utilized, and the Magic: The Gathering connection feels organic rather than forced. The characterization is particularly strong. The protagonist's inability to "turn off" their hacker mindset feels authentic and creates genuine internal conflict. Their self-awareness about the problematic nature of their observations adds depth. Maya is well-developed for a supporting character, with her own personality and realistic reactions that avoid the trap of being merely a plot device. The prose is clean and engaging, with good pacing and natural dialogue. The technical details feel authentic without becoming overly explanatory. The author effectively uses specific details (WiFi password format, phone models, unlock patterns) to establish credibility while maintaining accessibility for general readers. The story's emotional arc is well-constructed. The tension builds naturally from the protagonist's internal struggle, peaks with the awkward revelation about the unlock pattern, and resolves in a way that feels earned rather than artificially positive. Maya's response is believable - she's put off but intrigued rather than simply forgiving, which adds realism. The ending strikes an appropriate balance. The protagonist doesn't magically overcome their compulsions, but finds someone who might understand their quirks. The final line about not mentioning the WiFi password shows growth without complete transformation, which feels authentic. Minor weaknesses include some slightly repetitive internal commentary about the protagonist's compulsions, and a few moments where the technical exposition could be more seamlessly integrated. However, these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness of the piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 87.2
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Overthinking It Okay. Okay okay okay. This is fine. This is completely fine. Mr. Henderson just said "pair up with your lab partner," and my lab partner is Marcus, and Marcus is walking over here right now, and I'm going to say something normal like a normal person who says normal things. "Hey." That was him. He said hey. Say it back. Say hey back. "Hey." Good. Great. Excellent. One syllable, perfectly executed. I'm basically a conversational genius. He's pulling out the stool next to me. He's sitting down. His elbow is approximately seven inches from my elbow. I measured that with my eyes just now, which is definitely a normal thing that normal people do. Stop looking at his elbow. Look at the paper. The assignment sheet. Words. Read them. *"Design an experiment to test the effect of different liquids on plant growth."* I have thoughts about this. I have approximately fourteen thoughts about this, actually, because I read ahead in the textbook last week—not because I'm a nerd, well okay because I'm a nerd, but also because reading is easier than whatever my brain does when I'm not reading, which is basically this, this exact spiral I'm in right now. Say one of the thoughts. Pick a thought. Say it out loud. "So I was thinking—" He looked up. Eye contact. Abort. No wait, don't abort, that's weird. Maintain eye contact. No, that's too much eye contact. Look at his nose. No, that's weird, he'll think you're staring at a booger. Look at the paper. Point at the paper like you're referencing something specific. "—maybe we could use like, different pH levels? Like acidic versus basic solutions?" My voice did that thing. That thing where it goes up at the end like I'm asking permission to have an idea. I hate that thing. I practiced this in the mirror last night—not this specific sentence, but sentences in general, and I specifically practiced not doing the voice-going-up thing, and I did it anyway. "Yeah, that's cool," he says. Cool. He said cool. Does cool mean actually cool, or does cool mean 'I'm just agreeing so we can get this over with'? His face isn't giving me any data. His face is just... a face. A nice face. A face I definitely don't think about during math class when I should be thinking about quadratic equations. There's a smell. Ammonia. Someone cleaned something recently, probably the counter, probably after whatever disaster happened in third period because there's always a disaster in third period. The smell is sharp and it's cutting through my thoughts and now I'm thinking about the smell instead of thinking about what to say next, which is actually kind of a relief, but also Marcus is waiting for me to say something else, and— "We'd need a control group," I say. "Plain water." "Right, yeah." He's writing that down. He's writing down something I said. My words are becoming his words on the paper. This feels significant in a way that I know, intellectually, is completely ridiculous. I should say something else. Something not about the project. Something that indicates I'm a human person with interests and a personality and not just a science-fact-dispensing robot. People do this. People have conversations. I've observed them doing it. I've taken mental notes. *Hey, did you watch the game last night?* No. I don't watch games. Any games. He would ask follow-up questions and I would be exposed as a fraud. *That's a cool shirt.* It's a plain gray shirt. That's a weird thing to say about a plain gray shirt. He'd think I was hitting on him. I mean, I am hitting on him, in my mind, constantly, but he can't know that. *Do you have any pets?* Too random. He'd wonder why I was asking. He'd think I was gathering information about him. Which I am. But he can't know that. The ammonia smell is back, or maybe it never left, and now I'm worried that I smell like ammonia, that somehow the ambient cleaning product has bonded with my skin and he's sitting there thinking *why does she smell like a hospital floor*— "What liquids should we use?" he asks. "Besides water?" Oh thank God, a direct question. I can answer direct questions. Direct questions are my safe harbor in the storm of unstructured social interaction. "Vinegar for acidic. Baking soda solution for basic. Maybe... orange juice? For like, a mild acid?" I'm talking too much. I'm dominating the conversation. He's going to think I'm one of those people who has to control everything, who doesn't let anyone else contribute, who— "Orange juice is smart," he says. "My mom has some at home. I could bring it." He's contributing. He's offering to bring supplies. We're collaborating. This is going well. This is going well, right? His hand moves across the paper and for one horrible second I think he's reaching toward me and my entire body goes into red alert, every nerve ending suddenly online and screaming, but no, he's just reaching for the eraser, he's erasing a misspelled word, I'm an idiot, I'm such an idiot. "Sounds good," I say, and my voice is too quiet, and I want to say it again louder but then I'd be saying "sounds good" twice and that's weird, that's definitely weird, so I just nod instead, but now I'm nodding too much, I'm like a bobblehead, stop nodding— "Cool," he says again. Cool. I look down at the paper where our experiment is taking shape, his handwriting mixing with my suggestions, and I think: twenty more minutes. I can do twenty more minutes. I can sit here and smell ammonia and say science words and not spontaneously combust from the effort of appearing normal. He taps his pencil against the desk, a little rhythm, and I wonder what song is in his head. I'll never ask.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a strong understanding of the assignment requirements, delivering an authentic first-person narrative from an 8th-grade girl with social anxiety. The writer successfully captures the exhausting mental gymnastics of overthinking every social interaction, creating a believable and relatable character voice. The internal monologue structure works exceptionally well, showing the stark contrast between the protagonist's articulate inner thoughts and her stilted external communication. The stream-of-consciousness style effectively mirrors how anxiety spirals work, jumping between observations, self-criticism, and rehearsed responses. The voice feels genuinely adolescent without being condescending or overly cute. Character development is nuanced and authentic. The protagonist's intelligence shines through her scientific knowledge and self-awareness, while her social anxiety manifests in realistic ways - measuring distances with her eyes, overthinking eye contact, catastrophizing normal interactions. Her crush feels age-appropriate and genuine rather than romanticized. The dialogue, though minimal, serves its purpose well. Marcus's simple responses ("Hey," "Yeah, that's cool") feel natural for a teenage boy, while the protagonist's scientific contributions show her comfort zone. The contrast between her internal eloquence and external awkwardness is well-executed. The sensory details (ammonia smell, physical proximity) ground the scene effectively without becoming overwrought. The science classroom setting provides natural structure for their interaction while allowing the protagonist's expertise to emerge. The ending strikes an appropriate note - neither falsely optimistic nor unnecessarily dark. The protagonist's small victory of surviving the interaction while acknowledging her ongoing limitations ("I'll never ask") feels earned and realistic. Some minor weaknesses include occasional repetitive phrasing in the anxiety spirals, though this could be argued as intentionally mimicking anxious thought patterns. The piece maintains strong coherence throughout and avoids common pitfalls like purple prose or unearned character transformations. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 86.8
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Rehearsing Rejection The hallway mirror catches me adjusting my collar for the third time. My shoulders are hunched forward like I'm already bracing for impact, spine curved into a question mark. I look away before I can catalog anything else. *You're being pathetic again.* That's what she'll think when she sees me. Sarah. She'll open her door and her eyes will do that quick flicker—up, down—and she'll see exactly what I see: someone trying too hard, someone who texted three times yesterday when once would have been enough, someone who— "Hey, I've missed you," she'll say, but she'll say it the way you say "how are you" to a coworker. Automatic. Empty. *And what will you say back?* I'll say "I missed you too" and my voice will crack slightly on "too" and she'll hear it, she'll hear the desperation leaking through, and something in her face will close off. A door shutting behind her eyes. *Then what?* Then we'll sit on her couch and she'll keep her phone face-up on the cushion between us, checking it every few minutes, and I'll pretend not to notice. I'll ask about her week and she'll give me the highlights version, the version you give someone you're already mentally filing under "past tense." "Work's been crazy," she'll say. "Sorry I've been distant." *Distant.* She'll use that word. And I'll nod like I understand, like I haven't spent the last five days constructing elaborate theories about what "distant" really means. *It means she's done with you.* I know. *It means she finally saw what everyone eventually sees.* I *know.* *It means—* My phone buzzes. **Sarah:** *Can't wait to see you. Grabbed that wine you liked from last time ❤️* I read it four times. The heart emoji. She remembered the wine. She *remembered*. Something in my chest cracks open, warm and desperate, and I hate how quickly the warmth floods in, how starved I am for it, how a single red heart can restructure my entire nervous system in seconds. *She's just being nice.* But the wine. She went out and bought it specifically. That's not nothing. That's— *Guilt. She feels guilty about pulling away, so she's compensating. Classic.* I start walking toward her apartment, phone clutched in my hand like a talisman. *You know what's going to happen, right?* She's going to tell me this was a mistake. The sleeping together. She's going to use words like "complicated" and "timing" and "I care about you so much, but—" *But.* The "but" will do all the work. The "but" will be a knife dressed up in an apology. And I'll sit there and I'll nod and I'll say "I understand" because what else can you say? If I get angry, I'm proving her right—proving I'm too much, too intense, too *everything*. If I cry, same thing. So I'll be calm. I'll be so fucking calm she'll probably feel relieved, probably think *oh good, she's taking this well*, not knowing that I'm already rehearsing this exact conversation, already building the scar tissue in advance. *You're doing it again.* I know I'm doing it again. *The thing where you—* I *know*. But knowing doesn't stop it. Knowing just adds another layer: now I'm anxious *and* I'm watching myself be anxious, which makes me anxious about being anxious, which— Her building. I'm here. I press the buzzer. "Come up!" Her voice through the intercom sounds warm. Genuinely warm. *She's a good actress.* Or maybe she's not acting. Maybe— *Don't.* The stairs feel longer than usual. I'm rehearsing my face, trying to arrange it into something that looks normal, casual, like I haven't spent the entire walk here prosecuting a trial that hasn't happened. She opens the door before I knock. "Hi." She's smiling. She pulls me into a hug immediately, tight, her hand pressing flat against my back, and she holds it for a long time. Longer than politeness requires. I can smell her shampoo, something coconut, and my throat tightens. "I really missed you," she says into my shoulder. "I'm sorry I went quiet. Work stuff, family stuff—it all hit at once." She pulls back and looks at me and her eyes are doing the opposite of what I imagined. They're soft. Open. She reaches up and touches my face, just briefly, thumb brushing my cheekbone. "You okay?" *Say yes. Normal people say yes.* "Yeah." My voice comes out strange. "Yeah, I'm okay." She takes my hand and leads me inside. The wine is already open, breathing on the counter. Two glasses. She poured them before I arrived, which means she was waiting, which means— *Which means nothing. Stop.* But I can't stop. Even as she hands me the glass, even as she sits close enough that our knees touch, even as she starts telling me about her sister's divorce and her impossible deadline and how she thought about calling me six times but felt guilty about being bad company—even then, I'm scanning for the trap door. "I kept wanting to reach out," she says. "But I was such a mess. I didn't want to dump it all on you." *She didn't want to burden you.* Or she didn't want to talk to me. *She's literally telling you she wanted to talk to you.* People lie. *She bought the wine.* People lie with wine too. She's looking at me now, waiting for a response, and I realize I've been quiet too long. "You can always call me," I say. "Even when you're a mess. Especially then." Her face does something complicated and tender. "I know," she says. "That's what scares me sometimes. How much I actually believe that." She leans in and kisses me, soft, and I let myself fall into it for three full seconds before the voice starts up again. *She said "scares." She said you scare her.* That's not what she— *Isn't it?*
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of borderline personality disorder and the internal experience of anticipatory rejection. The writer successfully captures the exhausting cycle of catastrophic thinking, brief moments of hope, and immediate return to suspicion that characterizes this mental health condition. The narrative structure is well-executed, alternating between the protagonist's imagined scenarios and actual events. The italicized internal voice creates an effective dialogue between different aspects of the character's psyche. The prose maintains consistency in voice throughout, staying true to the anxious, hypervigilant perspective of someone with BPD. The characterization is nuanced and believable. The protagonist's reactions feel authentic - the way they physically brace themselves, over-analyze text messages, and immediately question positive interactions rings true. Sarah's behavior is also realistic, showing genuine care while the protagonist filters everything through their trauma lens. The writing demonstrates strong technical skill. Sentences flow naturally and the pacing effectively builds tension. The imagery is precise without being overwrought - details like "spine curved into a question mark" and "building the scar tissue in advance" are evocative without feeling forced. The piece successfully avoids several common pitfalls. There's no miraculous transformation or sudden insight that "fixes" the character. The ending maintains the established psychological pattern while showing a moment of genuine connection that the protagonist immediately questions. This feels earned and realistic. The emotional complexity is particularly strong. The reader experiences both the protagonist's desperate need for validation and their inability to accept it when offered. The cognitive dissonance is palpable and creates genuine empathy without romanticizing mental illness. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the internal dialogue becomes slightly repetitive, though this may be intentional to mirror the obsessive thought patterns of BPD. The piece could have benefited from slightly more concrete sensory details in places. + Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 80.2
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Blood Debt The temple had been dead for a century, but tonight it breathed again with the heat of living hatred. Torchlight carved shadows across crumbling stone walls where devotional murals had long since faded to ghosts. The courtyard's flagstones, buckled by decades of frost and neglect, formed an uneven arena roughly fifteen meters square. Spectators pressed against the colonnade's remaining pillars—perhaps forty souls in total, their faces half-illuminated, half-devoured by darkness. Money changed hands in whispered transactions. The air smelled of torch smoke, autumn rot, and the copper anticipation of violence. Katsuro Endo stood at the courtyard's northern edge, his bare feet planted on cold stone. The red-and-black armband of Jigen-ryū encircled his left bicep like a brand. He was twenty-three, lean as a hunting dog, with the coiled stillness of a man who had spent ten thousand hours learning to kill in a single breath. His bokken—a wooden training sword, but one carved from iron-dense red oak—hung at his left hip. His right hand rested on the grip, thumb against the guard. Twelve meters away, at the southern edge, Chen Weiming rolled his shoulders and let his arms hang loose. His own red-and-black armband marked him as Piguaquan, though his school had no formal name—only a lineage of bodyguards, caravan protectors, and men who fought for rice money in alleys where honor was a luxury. He was twenty-five, broader than Katsuro, with the thick wrists and scarred knuckles of someone who had learned combat through consequence rather than ceremony. He wore no weapon. He needed none. "Your master forbade this," Chen said, his Mandarin-accented Japanese cutting through the crowd's murmur. "Mine didn't bother. He knows I'll do what I want." "My master," Katsuro replied, "will forgive me when I bring him your broken body as proof that peasant tricks cannot stand against true swordsmanship." Chen smiled—a thin, dangerous expression. "Draw your stick, samurai. Let's see if your ancestors' ghosts fight better than you do." Katsuro's hand moved. The draw was everything Jigen-ryū promised: explosive, committed, a single ascending diagonal that covered the twelve meters between them in the space of two heartbeats. The bokken sang through torchlit air, aimed to split Chen's skull from left temple to right jaw. But Chen was already gone. He had read the shoulder rotation, the weight shift, the micro-tension in Katsuro's right forearm—and he had moved before the sword cleared its imaginary scabbard. His body twisted leftward, feet shuffling in a rapid half-circle that carried him outside the killing arc. The bokken's tip passed three centimeters from his nose. He felt the wind of it. His counter came from the rotation itself: a whipping backhand strike that used his entire body's momentum, shoulder and hip and planted rear foot all contributing to a palm-heel blow aimed at Katsuro's exposed right ear. Katsuro's forward momentum saved him. The strike grazed his skull instead of crushing it, but the impact still sent white fire through his vision. He stumbled two steps east, bokken extended, and pivoted to face Chen. They were now four meters apart. Chen had claimed the courtyard's center. Katsuro stood with a cracked pillar at his right shoulder. "First blood," someone shouted from the crowd. A trickle ran from Katsuro's scalp where Chen's palm had torn skin. Katsuro's expression didn't change. He shifted into middle guard—bokken held at sternum height, point aimed at Chen's throat. His breathing steadied. The pain became information rather than distraction. Chen began to circle. His footwork was deceptive: seemingly casual steps that actually maintained precise distance while constantly changing angles. He moved clockwise, forcing Katsuro to pivot with the pillar still limiting his rightward movement. His arms swung loosely, building potential energy for strikes that could come from any direction. Katsuro recognized the trap. He stepped forward and left, abandoning the pillar's constraint, and launched a horizontal cut at Chen's midsection. Chen dropped. His knees bent sharply, his torso folded, and the bokken passed over his head with centimeters to spare. From his crouch, he exploded upward with a rising elbow strike targeting Katsuro's chin. Katsuro jerked his head back. The elbow grazed his chest instead, but Chen was already continuing the motion—his rising body became a falling hammer as he brought his opposite forearm down toward Katsuro's sword-grip. The blow connected. Katsuro's fingers spasmed. The bokken clattered across flagstones. The crowd's roar was thunder in the ruined temple. Chen pressed his advantage. A whipping circular strike toward Katsuro's throat, then a low sweeping kick at his lead ankle, then another palm strike from an impossible angle as his body torqued through positions that seemed to violate skeletal logic. Katsuro retreated. One step. Two. His empty hands rose in desperate defense. Chen's strikes hammered his forearms, his shoulders, his ribs—each impact precise, each one accumulating damage like interest on a debt. But Katsuro was not merely defending. He was counting. Chen's rhythm had a pattern. The whipping strikes required recovery time—microseconds where his arms were extended, his center exposed. On the seventh strike, Katsuro stopped retreating. He stepped *into* Chen's attack. Chen's forearm crashed against Katsuro's shoulder, but Katsuro was already inside the arc, already driving his forehead into Chen's nose. Cartilage crunched. Blood sprayed black in the torchlight. Chen staggered backward, and Katsuro followed with a palm-strike to the solar plexus that folded him double. "Your ancestors," Katsuro whispered, "were dogs." He turned toward his fallen bokken. Chen straightened. Blood painted his lower face like a mask. His eyes held something beyond anger—something that had watched generations of his people bow to men like Katsuro. He moved. Katsuro heard the footstep and spun, but Chen was already airborne, his entire body becoming a weapon. The flying knee caught Katsuro in the sternum. They crashed together onto broken flagstones, and then Chen was mounted above him, raining down elbows and hammer-fists with the mechanical precision of a threshing machine. Katsuro's arms rose to protect his face. Chen broke through them. Once. Twice. Three times. On the fourth strike, Katsuro stopped moving. The crowd fell silent. Chen stood slowly, swaying. He spat blood onto the stones beside Katsuro's unconscious form. "Tell your master," he said to no one and everyone, "that the peasants send their regards." He walked into the darkness beyond the torchlight, and the temple returned to its century of silence.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution in several key areas while maintaining the gritty, visceral tone appropriate for an underground martial arts duel. The author successfully fulfills the prompt's demanding requirement for spatial coherence, meticulously tracking both fighters' positions throughout the encounter. The fight choreography is particularly well-executed, with clear descriptions of distance ("twelve meters apart"), positioning ("Chen had claimed the courtyard's center"), and movement dynamics that allow readers to visualize each exchange. The atmospheric opening effectively establishes the setting with evocative details like "torchlight carved shadows across crumbling stone walls" and the sensory description of "torch smoke, autumn rot, and the copper anticipation of violence." The characterization efficiently establishes the class conflict through both physical descriptions and dialogue, with Katsuro embodying aristocratic precision and Chen representing working-class pragmatism. The prose maintains consistent quality throughout, avoiding purple prose while still delivering vivid imagery. Sentences like "His body twisted leftward, feet shuffling in a rapid half-circle that carried him outside the killing arc" demonstrate technical precision without becoming overwrought. The pacing builds effectively from the initial tension through the explosive opening exchange to the final brutal conclusion. However, the piece suffers from some predictable elements. The outcome follows expected patterns - the arrogant aristocrat's initial advantage giving way to the street fighter's superior adaptability. The dialogue, while functional, occasionally veers toward cliché with lines like "Tell your master that the peasants send their regards." The characterization, though efficient, relies heavily on archetypal class dynamics without deeper psychological complexity. The ending feels appropriately dark and earned given the setup, avoiding false positivity while delivering a satisfying resolution to the established conflict. The technical fight sequences are the story's strongest element, demonstrating genuine understanding of martial arts mechanics and spatial relationships.
